reviewText:
Still VERY buggy as of January, 2014.

There are a LOT of things that are good about this game.  That only makes it more painful however when you get to the point that it is unplayable because of crashes.  I have a nice gaming rig, but the game has progressively become less and less stable to the point where now I cannot complete even one whole turn.  In other words, it's unplayable.

If you are looking to buy this, I would advise you to wait and see what the discussions say about it after the next patch comes out.  The last one was in September, so we've been waiting for a good while for some fixes.  The next patch has been said to release in January or February.  Here's hoping it helps.

Until the stability is addressed, I would not recommend people buy it.

reviewText: I am actually glad that I decided to go through with this game despite the bad reviews that users have been giving it. At a glance, it looks a lot like most fantasy setting 4x hexagonal grid strat rpg games, but this one is by far more punishing. As an example, the Age of Wonders series, when you make a mistake in that game it is typically a simple process to work your way back out of it, time consuming, but simple. This game is a lot less forgiving, to the point that even with all the right moves, you downright have to be cheating to get anywhere at all. In one game I had a single hero at level 2, was barely managing to stay on top of 4 hexes of land, and then a SINGLE beginner difficulty AI warrior hero comes along and stomps me. in the same amount of time the AI had somehow magically managed to have a level 5 hero, with 2 maxed abilities, and another with three points in it, which as far as I know so far, is not evne possible. So, all in all I definitely would have to give this game a 7/10, just for the sake of the mind-numbingly stupid situations I find myself in because of the balancing.

reviewText:
The best way to describe Eador: Master of the Broken World is that is very much like heroes of might and magic or other hex based, turn based combat games mixed with a strategic map more alike something from the total war series.

But unlike other games set in alike setting, you do not get to chose race, however in its place is a karma system and so you still deal with creatures of different alignments and it also extends to the strategic events and affects such things as random events.

There are a few problems, namely the random nature of events and not knowing what causes it. I felt that it took a good while before things became clear to the players as to what might trigger within certain terrain, by certain races and for what reasons. While some might argue that it keeps things fresh and you on your toes at all times, I found it at least as much frustrating to be punished for things I couldn't possibly predict.

Because of this, some other random elements and because of limited knowledge of unit composition and generally what a good way is to start, I would say this game has a very steep learning curve. For some this might be a strictly bad thing, while others might enjoy figuring things out.

It should also be said that the more you learn, the more restricted you might feel as some choices are real not much of a choice at all, like your starting hero for example.

Sometimes the games can drag on, and because the game is repetitive in its nature, due to how the campaign is played by generating a new map with a basic start for every single new world you try to take over, progression can feel slow and unrewarding between maps.

But overall, it can be very tactically challenging and worthy the time of those who enjoy some management and above all this style of hex based turn based combat.

reviewText:
Okay, I enjoy this game. I enjoy it alot. I have dumped alot of time into the game. If you like Strategy/RPG mix overall I think this game is something to look at. I won't hide the fact that the game is still buggy even after being out for a year, but the developers have been patching the game non-stop since it came out April 2013.

The Ugly:

Okay this game still has bugs, for some people game breaking bugs, and for others bugs that are iritating enough that can make it painful to play the game sometimes. The game was released last April almost completely unplayable, and over the past year it has improved for the major part. Yet I won't gloss over the fact that their is still alot wrong with the game.

The Bad:

The game probably is not all that balanced. Their are 4 tiers of units, and some T4 units could trample an entire army. Not all of the Hero classes are balanced. Their are 4 of them, but they all are playable. It will be nice to see what the game is like in the future.

The Good:

Did I mention patching? The developers still care about the game. They have been patching it a while, and still patch it.

There is alot in this game, alot of units, alot of choice. Alot of lore burried deep within a rough exterior. The game does not look half bad. The game is not fast paced, but is the type of game you can start playing, and come back between turns as you do something else, but will also keep you wanting to play one more turn" when things are getting good or you near to beating another map. The developers have recently added a boat load of new units and spells
date:
and have dropped hints are future expansion to the game.


Is the game
recommended: worth $19.99? Its a hard sell considering how buggy it can still be. I do thing its a hard sell
hoursPlayed: but I've enjoy the time I've dumped  into the game and I do appreciate the patches that have gone into it. The game has gotten good

reviewText:
(This review is from my opinion and has doesn't cover any issues the game others claim it may have.)

Well worth the money and time invested.

It's a game that keeps you coming back so long as you're not a casual player. Has the hardest campaign I've ever played by far and I'm still playing on beginner without finishing or starting a new campaign for the whole time I've actually spent playing the game (over 190hrs).

But it's been time well spent. The style of the artwork, the units, the models, the abilities and depth just work sooo well together.  I ACTUALLY feel like I'm in control of a kingdom while I'm playing. My choices have meaning and consequence/benefits. Although thats obvious when you play some games. I feel if I had to choose between games like ROME total war, Age of wonders series, Civ 5 etc, all those turn-based conquest stratagy games, I'd rather uninstall the rest than stop playing this one. But thats just my opinion.

The game in full could be taken furthur if the developers spent the same amount of time they spent making the game to make it go ever furthur. More intereactions, more interesting situations your kingdom might face, THINGS like shards clashing in the middle of conquering one shard then 2 more enemy kingdoms rock up that were originally clashing on that shard to begin with now I have to conquer both with more mayhem to add to the mix. The forging of alliances out of shards with other demi-gods, THE LIST is endless.

For what it is though it's amazing and a true inspiration towards what fantasy games should be/feel/look like. Not to mention the idea of shards and it's turn based stratagy while conquering territories. Well done! ^_^

p.s to myself: This review after reading does not serve the game justice, I feel its more than what I described by far but I couldn't find the words :(

reviewText: This game is certainly not easy. Be prepared to start over a lot, but each time you learn a little more to help you with your strategies the next time. reviewText: An innovative spin on the turn-based strategy genre. Compare to Heroes of Might and Magic or Disciples. Well worth the money it features near endless gameplay, diverse maps, interesting characters, and tons of quests, loot, enemies, buildings, and units to play with. You can also be as kind a ruler as you wish, or as evil a tyrant. Eador has some cons; a diplomacy system that is extremely limited and almost completely non-user firendly (I have yet to successfully forge an alliance with another master while on a shard). It also forgoes a totally pure RPG system like the Heroes series as heroes don't carry over between maps. So while you can level up to your hearts delight within a shard, all those experience points and high-powered items are lost once you beat it. Your deity character is also non-customizable and has little effect on actual gameplay. But besides these minor qualms fans of the TBS genre should pick this one up.

reviewText:
Pros:
- Lengthy campaign
- Well designed and flexible turn-based combat system
- Random event/world generation
- Overflowing with elements from other genres to add depth
- Multiple playstyles can be effective
- Well implemented auto-save system

Cons:
- Campaign is a bit too lengthy due to repetition
- Still riddled with bugs that can be game breakers
- No voice audio, entirely text-driven plot
- Erratic AI behaviour and levelling

Ultimately if you are a fan of the turn-based strategy genre then you probably won’t want to miss out. But until Snowbird either adds in a whole new raft of features (multiplayer options, alternate ways to conquer shards) then for the sake of pretty graphics it’s hard to imagine why you would pay upwards of £20 for an identical remake of a game that is still available for £2 - especially in a genre where graphics are less than a secondary concern.  The amount of bugs and crashes I experienced as well as the constant repetitiveness makes this a hard game to recommend but at the same time I have enjoyed the game and how exceptionally well this game is put together beneath the surface.  Juggling multiple management systems and tieing them to karma, story and making the whole experience fluid is not something to dismiss on a whim, however that already appeared to be present in the original game, so the question remains: what value has Snowbird Games really brought to Eador?  That is a question I struggle to answer, even after 98 hours.

A (now) solid turn based strategy game that stands shoulder to shoulder with many others but perhaps not quite matching the immersion that the Heroes of Might and Magic series provided.  What it lacks in story and frills it more than makes up for with in depth mechanics and gameplay however it is difficult to see anyone who is pressed for time or ambivalent about this genre sticking with Eador beyond the first few hours - especially when the tutorial alone took me 6 hours because I hadn’t realised there was no need to explore everywhere to 100%!  It’s a shame as the game really comes alive after the first few hours of invading a shard when you get the tier 3 and 4 creatures involved to take on the larger encounters in the game.

7/10

reviewText: I give it a 6.  I got about 15 hours out of it before I got bored.  It's a great concept and very ambitious.  The game gets bogged down in tedious combat, unbalanced units, and dumb AI.  Normal units require too much baby sitting to really level, but that's okay because high level heros dominate the field single-handed.  The strategic game lacks too: You're too busy conquering new areas (or re-conquering) to really explore or do quests except as side effect.  The meta-strategic is also neat, but you're so rarely there that it's more an aside than core gameplay.\nReally, I enjoyed what they were trying to do here, but I'd rather go play something a little more complex, such as Elven Legacy.

reviewText: MotBW, at it's heart, is a very good game. The mechanics are solid, the art is great, and the replayability is high. However, the game suffers from very poor balance and many, many bugs, some of which can be game-breaking. The developers seem to be keeping on this, and have recently released several patches that address some of the major flaws. I would hope that they continue to focus on this aspect (bugfixing) before moving on to others, such as any expansions that have been rumored. Overall this is very enjoyable 4X game, despite the aforementioned bugs. I do reccomend it to people with the patience to watch a fairly 'ok' game evolve into a great one, hopefully.

reviewText:
I've played Eador for some hours and nearly two days non-stop. It is a promising game, really a masterpiece of a crossover between Civilization and Heroes of Might and Magic, the battles are really difficult but still fair, with the exception of 1-2 enemy units. It is a lot of fun for ppl who like to manage a lot, but still enjoy a nice battle every now and then.

The main flaw why I wouldnt recommend this game is, because on the technical side it's a mess. Errors prompting up every 5-30 minutes, most of them just stop the game from running, the minimum specs are a lie and the loading times are unbelievably long. You could say that in a playtime of 8hours you effectively have played 3-4.

Still I would recommend Eador for being one of those games that really fascinate you, if you give it the chance and maybe have a good PC, the game is still a work in progress so maybe it will get better in time.

reviewText:
While not a giant like AoW or the early Homm Series this game holds its own as a grand strategic game with some development and roleplaying aspects. It has a fairly steep learning curve so be prepared for some level of frustration unless you procede carefully.

The economics determine your success or failure so be sure to think before buying armies willynilly. Scout/Warrior are best for starting out.

Fair warning: this game will eat up your time if you attempt the campaign mode. And there is a significant chance that there will be game killing errors. I still recommend it but with the caveat that you are buying a deeply flawed and yet beautifully implemented long time scale game.

reviewText: If you enjoy the old school Heroes of Might and Magic you'll like this game. It takes out some of the more frustrating resource management by reducing the types of resources from 6 to 2. Heroes feel a little underpowered in this game, but the four classes are pretty well balanced. The campaign mode adds a nice level of strategy. While each shard you conquer feels like its own world, and is a brief heroes of Might and Magic style game unto itself, the strategic brilliance is in how they link each conquest. As you conquer shards you obtain benefits and unlock technology that you can use in later conquests...for a price. The writing could use some polish, and it's difficult to pin down exactly, but it feels at times as though maybe a less than thorough job was done translating the game from another language. The real gold of this game is in its expanse. It is basically impossible to completely explore every shard, or at least would take a very long time, and the game does a nice job of providing you with new and different encounters. Do I want to try and forge an alliance with the elves on this shard or the halflings? Is it worth the time or should I just slaughter them all and take their lands? Should my hero spend his time hunting down that dragon that's plagueing my kingdom or should he pillage my enemy's domain? It's also nice to be confronted with actually insurmountable obstacles from time to time. No I can't explore this laborynth and kill it's minotaur at level one, but just because I can't face it, doesn't mean I can't see it. So many games have the you'll get there when you're ready" mentality and it negatively affects suspension of disbelief.\n\nThe story is fairly generic fantasy
date: but Astral politics can be fun
recommended: and it's nice that the way you treat your subjects and those around you has a concrete effect on the way they interact with you. That being said
hoursPlayed: being a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ isn't all bad like it is in some games. Some races respect bloodthirst and power. As a do-gooder
voteText: I constantly had my orc provinces in rebellion because they view me as oppressive and weak. Certain Astral entities will ally with you out of fear or respect for power rather than just sycophantic loyalty to kindness.\n\nAll in all I very much enjoy this game. Is it Shakespeare? No
helpfulPercent: but it certainly passes the time."

reviewText:
Okay, I enjoy this game. I enjoy it alot. I have dumped alot of time into the game. If you like Strategy/RPG mix overall I think this game is something to look at. I won't hide the fact that the game is still buggy even after being out for a year, but the developers have been patching the game non-stop since it came out April 2013.

The Ugly:

Okay this game still has bugs, for some people game breaking bugs, and for others bugs that are iritating enough that can make it painful to play the game sometimes. The game was released last April almost completely unplayable, and over the past year it has improved for the major part. Yet I won't gloss over the fact that their is still alot wrong with the game.

The Bad:

The game probably is not all that balanced. Their are 4 tiers of units, and some T4 units could trample an entire army. Not all of the Hero classes are balanced. Their are 4 of them, but they all are playable. It will be nice to see what the game is like in the future.

The Good:

Did I mention patching? The developers still care about the game. They have been patching it a while, and still patch it.

There is alot in this game, alot of units, alot of choice. Alot of lore burried deep within a rough exterior. The game does not look half bad. The game is not fast paced, but is the type of game you can start playing, and come back between turns as you do something else, but will also keep you wanting to play one more turn" when things are getting good or you near to beating another map. The developers have recently added a boat load of new units and spells
date:
and have dropped hints are future expansion to the game.


Is the game
recommended: worth $19.99? Its a hard sell considering how buggy it can still be. I do thing its a hard sell
hoursPlayed: but I've enjoy the time I've dumped  into the game and I do appreciate the patches that have gone into it. The game has gotten good

reviewText:
Really love this game. Not too difficult and not too easy, just right. This is a TBS type of game. The world consists of shards, which you have to conquer. Every shard consist of a number of provinces. Your hero (as usual you can have a number of them) has to conquer the provinces. Once a province is conquered you can explore it (find treasure, etc. usually leading to a fight or negotiation) pleasing the local population make money from them build mining facilities, mills etc. There are many kind of buildings to build and paths to choose.

In between, events take place that you must resolve in some way. For instance there is some wizard that resurrects some death people and you have to decide whether to fight the wizard, pay it off or ignore it (just making this one up as an example).

Fights bring you to a hexagonal field which is pretty much standard across TBS type of games and you have to fight the enemy with the army you have (pretty much like you have it in other TBS games like king's bounty).


Loads of fun and highly recommended.

reviewText:
The last time I extensively played Eador was back in summer of 2013, outside of Steam. The game was quite new. It had tons of bugs but it was mostly playable. However it was no secret it was unfinished and many important mechanics did not work. But the small team of developers really deserve a load of respect because now a year and dozends of patches later - after many fans may have given up their hope on Eador and even taunted the creators Masters of the Broken Game" on their official support forums - the game is great.

My comeback to the game today was worth and to honor the good work on the game the devs put into it I decided to buy it on Steam. I never thought they could recover this game and even more important giving the UI a needed refresh. By today the game is like it should have been at release - it is fun and can be challenging.

There are still some drawbacks: it can be confusing to learn how to conquer the shards and how the whole works.
The AI may be still better. The monsters
date:
items and events you face on the shards are very repetitive. Not to start talking about the music.  Apart from that I would give Eador a good 6 of 10 rating.

If you have some time kill and you love to combine strategy with roleplay elements  it is definitely worth the few bucks it costs! In strategic aspects how creatures are fighting each other it reminds me a bit of Magic the Gathering.

Bad luck for Windows 8 users this game needs .NET Framework 3.5 to be installed to work properly.

I rate the game with a 7/10.

1 point less for the repetitive music and missions
1 point less for the remaining bugs (mostly AI) and crashes
1 point less for the fact you have to delete a preexisting profile and start a new campaign to unlock steam achievements
recommended: also to get access to the DLC. if you played Eador before you got it on Steam and like to play on like me
hoursPlayed: it will be troublesome."

reviewText:
Was kinda leary about this title as the game story seemed a bit odd (shards of a world floating aimlessly in space?  Really?)  I recieved it in a 5 dollar bundle deal.  Playing through the tutorial seamed a bit clunky and glitchy, but that was just the tutorial.  After the first few days of playing (countless hours of playing) , wow, I really like this game.
I will use an analogy from the game story to describe the game.  Its like a gem broken into pieces floating aimlessly, spend some time collecting and putting them together, well, its a gem to behold (thus far).
Its not your typical pick a race, class, here are your abilities, now get to it game.  The shards you attempt to conquer, will add to your abilities and somewhat define and refiine your strategy.  The game has been a pleasant journey of discovery as it doesnt come with a manual (although you can find the manual through google translate if you need game info).  Shards of different gametypes, pieced together (ex: HoMM, Masters of Magic, Warlords, etc) and its friggen extensive.  I am over 40 hours in and not even halfway through.   Altogether, it works for me and if you like these kind of games, you should find this a unique experience as well.
Did I mention the game is huge?  Some shard battles I take time to do some quest, others I have been forced to finish fast as the enemy gives me difficulties (I started playing on skilled mode).  I have heard complaint that the game gets redundant or repetative.  What game do you enjoy playing that doesnt get repetative?  The game solves this with some auto functionality.  You can just quickview the battle, or set it to auto and watch the battle play out.  Sometimes I am forced to do the manual battle as the AI doesnt do the strategy required to win.  It will say this should be easy then you lose your entire army.  The game does save every minute or so and I suggest you do some manual saves (just in case, as there is no restart scenario option).  In all its a minor annoyance in all the richness this game offers.
I have seen many gripes on the forums concerning this game, I have none here.  I guess you will either love it or hate it, but dont be swayed buy the naysayer if the above mentioned gametypes gave you some joy back in the day.  Eador:  Master of the Broken World is a worthy game.
Now if you will excuse me, I have some shards to conquer.

reviewText: I will update the review as I play more through the game.\n\nFirst thing: Eador: MoBW is hard, and immensely time consuming, if you are not a big fan of 4x and Turn-Based Strategy you'll hate this game, if you're not a fan of this genre already Eador will not transform you onto one. I have more than one hundred and twenty hours of gameplay and was only able to conquer ten shards, nevertheless know that to finish the game you need twenty five. This means approximately twelve hours per shard, therefore I am talking about three hundred hours of campaign. And I am only playing on the third hardest difficulty. I am sure that in the hardest one I would not be able to finish the game. This characteristic force you to use the best strategy you can think in order to do absolutely anything. Eador is a low-number-status game, so each single positive thing you can figure out will make a enormous difference, the same applies to negative ones. The terrain on the battle map is extremely important, the single 1+ defence" a hill give can make the difference between everything. Personally to me this is a positive point if I liked easy and casual things I would study art or some other meaningless area
date: not physics.\n\nThere is one thing that almost kill this game
recommended: the sense of progression. But the Eador's developers are one the the best on Steam
hoursPlayed: and even after two years they are trying to fix this problem through patches. It worked on certain aspect but the problem persists. After each shard you conquer (after ten hours) you goes back to the astral plane and have to start every thing all over again

reviewText: This game has become a solid entry into the 4x" genre at this point. You conquer the Eador world shard by shard. Each shard you conquer allows you to build a little bit better buildings.  The combat is turn based and is done very well. The variety of monsters
date: creatures you will face is also very nice. I am a little over 16 hours into the game and I am on my 4th shard and to be honest it is getting a bit repetetive at this point. There is no hero carry over from shard to shard so after you conquer a shard you then recruit a new hero for the next. I think this is where the game falls a bit. You spend hours working through a shard
recommended: building your main provicence and adding a couple of smaller buildings to the conquered provinces all the while leveling up your hero. This is honestly quite a bit of work and takes grinding to beat the shard. However once you beat the shard
hoursPlayed:
you lose all your progress and your hero. You essentially start the next shard at ground zero. Albeit you have access to a little bit better buildings but you do the same thing again. Start your hero at 0 and work on beating that shard.
This is a fun game and at this point of its life plays solid- however I do not see myself logging 60 hours due to the repeat process on each shard.
Things I think would make this game more enjoyable for longer play:
Carry over your hero and make the next shard a level harder. This way you feel you are building towards something as you play through. Right now on shard 4 I stopped because I have a level 0 Warrior and he just croaked on 3 imps with 4 barbarians with him. It is frustrating considering on shard 3 I grinded my Mage to a great level and was enjoying the game. Then .... he is gone once the shard is defeated.
Reduce the amount of searching in each province. To get to 100% per province takes quite a bit of time and is very repetetive. I find myself at this point in the game rolling my eyes when I hit nothing encountered 3x in a row and it becomes a click fest to see what you will find.
Add more heroes if you plan on keeping the new hero per shard. They are quite generic and there is no real customization you can do to make the new hero on the next shard feel different.
Right now you only have 4 to choose. I have already used all 4 and I am on my 4th shard. From what I read this game can reach 20+ shards per playthrough.
The good :
Pretty game. Graphics are solid.
Combat is quite fun. I do like the movement points and I do like the challenge as the fights are not easy.
The variety of monsters
voteText:
creatures encountered is very large.
Once you get the hang of city building with the wheel its pretty slick. I found myself realy enjoying the building aspect.

All in all .. this a solid 4x entry ....however if you are like me and enjoy customization of your characters and buidling your characters over the course of the game you will find this quite repetetive and almost a chore when you hit the next shard. (notice my frequest use of the word repetetive)

I would give it 7/10 based on solid gameplay

votesHelpful: combat but it falls a bit due to lack of hero diversity
votesTotal: growth
votesFunny:
and customization.

reviewText:
Incredibly deep 4x game. Steep learning curve and a bit buggy but still well worth the price of admission. Gameplay does get a bit repetitive but the sheer number of units, buildings and various strategies you can employ, in addition to the unique challenges presented by each shard ensures every shard skirmish feels unique from each other.

It's so fun leveling up your heroes, buidling armies, developing provinces, learning magic, buying items, exploring, casting rituals, hiring guards, conquering provinces, adventuring...this game really scratches an itch. Not for the faint of heart or someone seeking a casual game but definitely a gamer's game.

Only negative is it's a slow game and takes many, many hours to play....so enter if you dare!

reviewText:
First off, this isn't a BAD game, per se, it's just really......really....slow.

I like TBS games, and I like RPG games, and this has elements of both.  Think Heroes of Might and Magic style battles but with more RPG elements.  But I can tell this is going to be a long game, with lots of story/text.  Right out of the gate there's a lot of talking and it pretty much put me to sleep.  I mean, yes it was the campaign with tutorial settings, but I found everything just moved too slowly for my liking compared to some other games.

It's pretty basic, nothing really new to see at all, it's not horrible so I can't NOT recommend it, but don't expect it to blow your socks off.

5.5/10

reviewText:
Is the game worth it? Simply put yes - in a pure cost per hour it represents great value. But if you're looking for a flawless gem then this is not the game you're looking for, its greatest strengths are also its greatest weaknesses.

By all means buy the game, enjoy it for what it is and appreciate the depth of control you have and perfecting your chosen methods/tactics. However this is rather like a marathon - you do it once, maybe you talk about doing it again but when you get back in training you realise the memory is better than the actual experience and there are better things to do with your time.

When this game was first released the bugs made it torturous to play, despite its underlying appeal. The bug fixes and subsequent DLC addressed the vast majority of these and added some additional diversity into the game and the alliances you could build.

The unit progression is superb, allowing you to tailor to your playstyle while still retaining a small element of randomness. It's gratifying to see your minions grow and develop, reaching landmark skills/abilities and being able to deploy them accordingly. It's less gratifying to see them die on turn one of a battle before you can act. The realism of this is appreciated however anything resembling an offensive spellcaster is going to spend its life cowering at the back being chain healed awaiting the arrow that will finally kill it. After carefully nurturing them to a level where they get decent spells this is not entertaining. To avoid this you are left with only a small selection of units to use (or you go with a hero that does all the work while the creatures in the army are more like cheerleaders). The other failing is the high level units you can build are ultimately not needed meaning every level is the same army; the game fails to challenge you to change your playstyle, the 'differences' between the worlds are not level defining and every shard is the same. While I don't always like the myriad of missions that are often forced on players in games such as these the totally directionless play isn't rewarding. And just when you think it is you win the level and start from scratch.

My first playthrough was long, I inadvertently picked the longest win condition and proceeded to conquer every shard in turn. It was clear from the achievements there were a number of ways to win but none presented themselves. For me the replay value of a game is key, I love to go back and play games again in a different way, or using different tactics and this one is no different. Once I finished it I wanted to go back and play again; different heroes, different endings, different bonuses. The problem is after a shard or two I realised that I was going to be doing this for another 200 hours (and that there was no joy in trying to do it differently). While the longer I spend away from the game the more fondly I think of it a few hours playing it again drives me away.

I don't regret buying it, or the time spent. Perfecting the tactics, overcoming the AI's tendency to cheat spectacularly, finally closing down a shard and managing the grumpy inhabitants of the cities was something I enjoyed at the time. But not something I want to do again and it's something many people won't want to do at once.

Consider this a public service announcement: Game still glitchy as of December 25th, 2013.  I hope it is fixed sometime.

EDIT as of December 30th follows:

I've added another 40 hours of playtime, despite glitches and restarts.  Its a testament to the fact that I really do like the game.  I try to limit the number of actions I take per turn, to give the game less opportunity to fail.  But I've hit 3 turns in a row where I've had to restart, and after lengthy battles.

Like I said, if the game is fixed it will be great.  But until then it is a tantalizing tease of a game.  I'm not saying you should never buy it, but wait for it to be a working product.  Save yourself some time and frustration.

I intend to update this review in the future when the game is playable.

reviewText: The game has a large amount of rather interesting mechanics; for instance units gain new abilities as they level up and some of them change them dramatically (fairies get a dodge ability that makes it so being attacked by a higher level enemy makes them retreat unless they are cornered or out of stamina for instance). It is a pity that units are so relatively fragile you won't be seeing any of that most of the time. Heroes are relatively overpowered to everything so the game turns into leveling them up and dungeon crawling for money sidling the rest of the military and economic development that exists in game.\n\nGiven the amount of bugs this game has, I doubt they'll be fixing that fundamental issue which turns the game into a boring slog to level up your hero and then smash your opponent.

reviewText:
I saw videos and previews of this game a long time ago and thought it looked awesome. I really liked the idea of a turn based fantasy based strategy with tactical combat.

So when the game came out I waited a bit and then bought it. I'm honestly not sure what to think of this game. There is all the right pieces there for a awesome RPG tactical strategy game, but for some reason it just falls short.

The hero characters aren't very balanced and just feel kind of blah. The game gets very repetitive very fast as you keep running into the same thing over and over.

While playing I just couldn't help but compare it to Fallen Enchantress which is a similar style game. In pretty much every way it feel short. Maybe not fair as Stardock is a larger company. But still the point is there.

You may love this game, you may hate it. If you play Fallen Enchantress I'd stick with that and not bother with this game.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I'm not sure why this game has mixed user reviews. This game has so much depth, looks beautiful and my favourite thing about it - everything is transparent. There's a wealth of information in the game you can access by simply right-clicking and hovering over whatever, which makes learning the game a lot of fun. The combination of an (improved imo) Heroes of Might and Magic combat system with a 4x overworld map works really well.

Eador is the sort of game you can easily spend hundreds of hours in, the replayability is great. Not as much as Paradox games, but I feel like each run is different enough. Though this might be a con to others - a single game (called Shard ingame) could take anywhere from half an hour to 10 or even 20 depending on how large the Shard is.

It's a testament to how much I enjoy this game that I just get lost in it for hours on end; listening to the dreamy music, continually making and re-evaluating decisions, levelling up my dudes, conquering new lands. Give Eador a chance, it's a fantastic game!

reviewText:
I thought this game was a lot of fun for the first couple of hours, then it becomes tedious.

The hero exploration seemed like it would be a lot of fun, if it didnt take forever and all the combat wasn't manual.

The units are very imbalanced, you can spend a lot of time nurturing your troops just to have them one hit by someone elses tier 1 or 2 units.

There's also no real effective way to garrison your territory, so it plays a lot like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ game of risk, where you just make one massive army and roll across the map until you sack someones capital city.

reviewText: A game with a lot of potential, so perhaps I would recommend with a patch, but right now it seems to have a lot of little bugs. One particular one I have had happen to me on multiple occasions, you fight a battle and win but the hero dies after the battle for no reason I can see (during the battle he would have taken little or no damage).  The hero still shows on the map, and you can give him instructions, but he won't actually do them, so you check his status, and see it's because he's been stricken dead somehow.  Another is that during battle, even though I have auto-combat turned off, sometimes individual units will move or attack on thier own; it happens almost always after you have done something with another unit.  It's annoying and makes battle harder because you never know when a unit will decide to do thier own thing.

reviewText: Promising game, but too many big things wrong with it to recommend. Variety is sorely lacking - Units are divided into alignment, and despite a plethora of building construction becomes surprisingly linear based on what the surrounding area looks like, and there is only one player faction. Balance is bad too, with the margin for error being extremely unforgiving -  I couldn't make any headway even with the game set on beginner.\n\nThe setting, while enchanting, comes off as little more than your standard D&D story that we've all seen a hundred times. In the end, while strategy experts might enjoy it, there's just too many other strategy games with more depth and character.

reviewText:
Good strategic game.
The main advantage is that there are a lot of possibilities. There is no unbalanced/unbeatable combination of units, so you can play the game your style. For example Forests is good cover against ranged attacks and hills give you an advantage in melee fights. You don't have to kill all units, you can also reduce their moral to zero or reduce their stamina (that won't grant you the victory, but makes it way easier to kill them ;))

The Game is still a little bit buggy and freezes sometimes when you start a new shard and you have to play a different shard instead.

The Game develops slowly, you have to conquer a shard and as reward you get plans to build new buildings. You get the first tier II units after 3-4 shards.

reviewText:
I certainly got my mony's worth from this game considering the amount of playtime I got vs the price paid.

Having said that, while this is an entertaining game, the real problem, as with so many strategy games is that the AI poses no real challenge.  The other big problem is that the game-play is somewhat repetitive and you end up doing pretty much the same thing over and over on each shard.

One big complaint is that the AI ends up with some uber-guards to protect thier home city.  This ends up the case over and over and it is just a tiresome thing to deal with nearly every single shard you conqure.

While this is a fun game, it does have some major game-play problems.

reviewText:
Eador: Masters of the Broken World is a great game if you have a lot of time to spend, and do not mind a slow progression curve. Presenting you with a strategy game set in a detailed world broken up into multiple shards, you can spend your time gathering land and power to eventually find one of many endings.

It is a big game, full of strategic decisions and plenty of things you can explore, find, and control. It is one of the largest games in scale that I have seen so far, which is both good and bad. Good, because, of course. That's more game for you to play in, and bad because all that scale takes a lot of time to get through. So much time that you may not have enough in your schedule to make good progress in it - I have over 80 hours in it, and I have not yet completed the campaign. As much as I like the scale, the shattered vibrant world, the astral mechanics and the immersive soundtrack, it has issues that it doesn't need to have.

The world in Eador is based on shards, with each shard being a whole new map to explore and conquer, and every one you conquer brings you a new building or advantage you can take along to the next. You gain astral energy based on how much of the world is in your possession, and how many people worship you, the astral spirit/master controlling the place. The problem here is that every single shard has you build up your forces from practically nothing. You can spend energy to bring some basics, but it is never really enough to skip through the early game and expensive. Plus, who knows what else you may want your energy for? Eador plays much more like several similar skirmish maps than a long unified campaign. Yet, there is throughout it all a large storyline, from world to world, where you can spend time talking to the other masters or decide to engage them, change things that have long term effects far past the one world you're in, or otherwise find out more about the game's world.

While in the game itself, there are a lot of random and semi-random events as well. The world feels as if it is actually a world, rather than just a game through these. The soundtrack is very well done, and it is easy enough to forget about time and spend several hours to take over another shard and advance past it.
But it has issues, as mentioned. It is imperfect, with occasional crashes and some balance issues making it very difficult to progress at times, as well as some design decisions, whether intentional or not, leading to some choices being just plain better than others. Out of all this, the worst of it is when your opponent gets a random event that allows them to have a guard dragon, while you are still in the earliest levels. There is no way to defeat a dragon at that point without a lot of grinding experience on your hero and luck.

The opposing AI is rather poor, and at times does not seem to even understand the basics of gameplay, which is sad as you will be spending a lot of time beating on said AI. Both the other masters and the neutrals tend to be like that, sadly. The battles being on a tiny, simplistic map that shows that combat is not the game's strong point.

But you're likely not buying this for the combat. If you're buying Eador, you're doing it for the strategy, the long term plans, the vibrant world, and all the good things it has. Try to not let its faults get to you, and you will be able to spend litterally days on it without any regret. But if you do not have time, patience, or are not that much into strategy and similar 4X games, you may not enjoy it. For those who do enjoy those things, here's for you.

reviewText:
One of the best turn based games I have played.  After 277 hours I can say that I still found new things in the game today.  The campaign takes forever but it is well worth it.

What usually seperates games for me is do your choices matter and is the playability of the main function fun.  This satisfies both of those requirements.  You can win in a lot of different, satisfying ways.  I had mages who just fireballed everything or never cast a spell but summoned golems to destroy everything.  The warrior class is the strongest class by far but there are some challenges still if you play that class.

Pros:  Great gameplay, Solid graphics, Fun levelling for hero and units, awesome items, soundtrack is very good, solid strategy decisions and finally very challenging even if you are a veteran player.

Cons:  Interface is really tough especially on buildings, overpowered class(warrior/slayer) but really all heroes but commander.  Some of the events get tiresome and repetitive.

Overall this is well worth your money and more importantly your time if you like turn based games.

column16:
and also the vast catalog of equippable items and buildings to employ.

Cons
Other reviews really only harp on two things
column17: difficulty and bugs.  The bugs do exist
column18: and the game does crash.  There is an autosave feature that saves the game every turn
column19: which addresses this pretty well
column20: but it is still annoying.  It is NOT a reason to give up on
column21: or dismiss this game entirely.  The difficulty may be hard for people new to SRPGs.  For me
column22: I updated the difficulty level to "Expert" not too far into the game
column23: and I am not struggling on any one stage.  This concern is also well addressed because they have I think 8 options for difficulty and can be adjusted.  There is a learning curve with troop usage and all of the classes involved
column24:
but a huge variety of successful strategies to develop which truly makes this game interesting.

DLC
I recommend playing the game a bit first and making sure you dig it before buying.  You'll probably know pretty quickly.  If you do enjoy the game
column25:
the DLC is a welcome addition to it.

Summation
If you are looking for a turn based SRPG that you can play for 10 minutes at a time or easily lose an entire weekend to it all the same
column26: this is a solid choice.  This is the best SRPG I have been able to find since the PS1 era."

reviewText: An empire builder with terrible pacing. The visuals are beautiful, but the gameplay suffers from the fact that you can't field a mobile army unless you have a hero. Unfortunately, recruiting a hero beyond your first is prohibitively expensive, making the early parts of the game very boring or very frustrating depending on how you're progressing. Allowing players to march out troops without a hero or even allowing two free heroes at the start would help tremendously with the opening turns' dullness.\n\nAdditionally, the game features a separate tactical map for combat. It starts promising, but it doesn't take long before units appear that completely disrespect the terrain and simply fly past your frontline troops to decimate your ranged units.

reviewText:
Recommend if you have loads of time to burn.

I want to like this game but it is a bit of grind in the campaign. You'll invest a few hours on a shard to move to the next one just to unlock one more building. The game is fairly challenging which is good. Your lands are easily conquered and require your constant vigilance. Lands also revolt and succeed and so you send your limited units over to smack them down. Meanwhile, other lords are conquering the lands you just left. There's a good amount of random events that benefit or hurt you. There's also a fair amount of bugs that will hurt or annoy you like enemy units that are dropped to 0 hp but don't die. There also seems to always be a non-zero probability to lose a battle when you have an overwhelming force on auto-battle.

reviewText:
Really awesome game that captures fantasy and the idea of being a demigod perfectly. The combat is amazing and really fun, the graphics look great, the replayablity is insane, the random events are fun and well written. The game is really deep and extensive as well, with so many things to manage, upgrade and decide it's just a pure joy to play.

Oh, and if you ever played Eador before, this game is literally a 3rd remake of it in it's custom games. With even more content with the DLC.

The mixed status and the negative reviews are due to the I guess boring campaing, which is why people complain about not keeping their units and upgrades from shard to shard. The thing is, the campaign is supposed to just be a side thing, The best way to play this game is to go into a custom game, set up your settings, and then enjoy hours of fun as you attempt to conquer your shard.

reviewText:
i love eador. this or any version. i won't deny that masters of the broken world has it's flaws, but overall i love it. there are plenty of reviews out there that will tell you what can be improved about this game, so i just want to focus on the postive aspects. what i really enjoy is that you build buildings in your main province or territory to recruit troops, upgrade units, boosts production, learn spells-basically everything in the game. if you want to buy your own armor and weapons, you can build the buildings associated with it, but beyond that, as you conquer more territories and hire guards to partol and protect them from potential uprisings or invaders, you can also build more buildings in those territories to do things like hire troops, buy items and learn spells from your capital territory without having to be there. you can also construct buildings in those provinces to boost production of the different currencies and other resources across your empire.

i love that the different heroes allow for pretty widely varied playstyles. the scout/archer picks people off from a distance, the warrior is a one many army, the commander boosts his troops to near hero like levels and can have the largest number of troops on the battlefield, and the mage can be a range spellcaster, a healer, a necromancer with an army of the undead or a summoner of hellish hordes. the mage class is definitely my favorite. picking one hero at the start doesn't prevent you from getting the others later on, the cost goes up more and more, but you can keep buying new heroes and making more armies.

there's a huge range of enemies to fight and the battlefield itself adds extra depth to the combat. hills slow down movement but provide extra defense for melee combat and extra range for archers, forests provide cover from range attacks and hinder movement. the swamps also slow down units and reduce defense for troops unlucky enough to be in there when attacked. seemingly every enemy you come across in the story can potentially be recruited and used to fight for you. if you don't want to play for hours to unlock the better weapons, armor, monsters, etc., you can play a quick match on a custom shard against custom opponents and you'll start with all the buildings unlocked and the freedom to explore any playstyle you want.

reviewText:
I love turn based strategy games.  This game looks and feels a lot like Heroes of Might & Magic, but it has some flaws that holds it down from it’s true potential.  I’m writing this review for the TBS fans that know what they are looking for, and noting the exact flaws that ruin the game.

There are four tiers of strength for your recruitable units.  Each recruitable unit can level up.  However, no matter what high level they attain, they are really no match for the next higher tier unit.  No units can be resurrected, which can be infuriating when your tier 1, level 10 infantry is eliminated by a tier 3, level 0 archer in one strike.  I tried to cycle through my troops by only using my low levels to fight low level battles, but then you realize that your higher tiers would rather benefit from the experience, as they will need all they can get when they have to take on tier 4 enemies.  On top of that, the opponent AI will always bee-line to your weakest and most exploitable units first.  Battles have to be sought out, but are abundant.  The problem is low level encounters are just as rare as high level encounters.  All encounters are preset, and you can choose when to take on the encounter.  You might find yourself scouring the lands trying to find goblins for your tier 1, level 0s to knock out, wasting many turns in the process.  The best way to level up your army is for them to see combat head on, which makes it tough to build up solid armies without losing a few in the process.  I found myself sometimes recruiting low levels as simple cannon fodder or bait.  No units have a ‘taunt’ ability, so no unit can be used for ‘tanking.’ This greatly hurts the whole point of playing as a warrior type CO, and puts heavy armor defense infantry in a tough spot.  Most units can run or fly circles around them.  Terrain does play a role in mobility and stat adjustments, but not so much that it becomes a game changer.  Battles ultimately end up being very lopsided, with little actual strategy.

If it wasn’t for the core of the strategy being flawed, it would be a fantastic gem.  The graphics are very pleasing to the eye.  The soundtrack is limited and repetitive like an old console game, but can be turned off.  The interface may look intimidating at first, but it is simply spread out and unconsolidated, which doesn’t affect gameplay.  I only recommend it to those with a tremendous amount of patience and time on their hands.  Expect campaigns to take many hours at a time, and anticipate never being able to take on many battles due to the limits of what army you can develop.  In short, expect disappointment, but do your best with what you have.

reviewText:
I'm struggling to find words insulting enough to convey how terrible this game is. It's simply a disaster on all levels.

Getting the game to run initially is a struggle by itself. The game files get flagged by AVG (something I've never seen before with a Steam title. After that, the game won't run because the game process is not killed and Steam will report an error. Even after forcibly terminating the process, steam still thinks you are running it. Ultimately you have to forcibly terminate Steam itself to fix it.


Once you finally get into the game, things get even more frustrating. Let me cover some key points to give a general idea of why I think the game is a POS.

First you customize your profile as lord- pick a portrait, emblem color, name etc- however this is mostly pointless because the only part of the customization that is retained is the name and emblem. I picked a cool portrait to suit my roleplaying preference, changed colors to black and white, but in the game my portrait reverted to the default one and the character model is fixed to all red armor with a particularly douchey looking haircut.

The games inability to let the player roleplay doesn't stop there either. You equip your guy with a nice shiny Axe and a shield, but the model does not change and in battle he uses a spear and sword. I've seen more roleplaying value in games that aren't even roleplaying games.

No UI scaling- Yeah this game doesn't have it. If you are like me and many others that want to play at a decent resolution, then prepare to squint your eyes at the tiny UI or keep a magnifying glass in one hand as you play. There's really no excuse as to why a game like this is lacking such a rudimentary feature.


The combat- If you would call it that) is incredibly boring and lifeless. It's about as satisfying as peeling a potato. The animations are out of sync with the combat actions. The floating text and repercussions of an action happen before it has even been executed in a rather strange and detached way. Swinging a sword at an enemy looks and sounds like you've just slapped someone with a stick of celery. The combat lacks any meaningful impact and the enemies fall down in the most generic way shortly before they vaporize into a bunch of sticks ?

When a battle ends there is no reaction at all from your army, no war-cries, no chants, they just stand there like stunned-mullets like it never even happened. The battle map is so one-dimensional and generic looking. It doesn't make an effort to show any creativity and just slaps a bunch of hexes together on some slightly modulated ugly looking terrain.


I'd say the best part about this game is it's music, and even that's pretty average. Other than that, It's just a horrible uninspired, boring and lackluster approach to the genre with no redeeming value. In fact I can't think of a single thing this game does right.

Such a waste.

reviewText:
Eador Cons
1: You have to restart from scratch every level.
2: Instead of having more intelligent IA they just throw more resources and units at them really early on.
3: Game has a auto resolve button, but it's broken at best. Ex archer heroe with peasant army v dragons=win archer heroe with peasant army v wolf pack= lose.
4: recent update introduced invalid pointer error which causes the game to quit working when certain game events happen it can be worked around, but it's annoying.
5: The game overall is really slow to get going.
Pros
1: Every level you can pick a different route to go (different heroes, units, buildings, spells, good or evil, etc.)
2: You have to plan ahead when choosing buildings to create a good army.
3: Random events that can be good or bad, and you get to decide how to respond to them instead of just watching them happen.
4: Unit trees (good, neutral, evil) are balanced out.
5: You can have guards to defend your lands so you don't always have to make your heroes backtrack to deal with random events. (Which is really helpful during war times.) Guards also have effects on the lands they are stationed in.

All in all it's a good game if you can stand restarting every level, but I wouldn't recommend it till they fix the (invalid pointer error) problem.

reviewText: I must admit all the negative reviews put me off, but most of the top rated reviews were all positive. So I decided to pirate the game to see what it was like. I can honestly say that it was extremely fun and I decided to buy it the next day. For those who are new to the genre or maybe even the game, I recommend using beginner difficulty and playing the tutorial to get a grasp of the game mechanics. It's a fun game that requires you to think tactically on the battlefield and strategically about what 'shard' you want to conquer. It can be difficult at times, especially if you get a bad starting position, however this can be overcome when you get used to the game. However losing a shard isn't game over, as long as you have more than your opponent you're still in with a chance. Look if you're still not sure pirate the game, don't like it don't buy it, if you do like it buy it, simple. :)

reviewText:
I really want to like this game, but it just ends up being shy of good. The game has issues with bugs creaping in, but the developers are generally pretty quick at addressing them. Unfortunately you rarely get a fully working game. As old bugs are squashed, new ones creep in. Also, some bugs just don't go away, the worst is the bug where you can't end your turn. You're required to basically sacrifice your next turn by converting it into 'auto combat'. In many cases this just results in you losing the battle. This means that 5-10% of your battles you are required to reload, purely because they won't/can't fix this bug.

There's three aspects to the game. A campaign-wide strategy, a map strategy, and tactical maps/tactics in small combats. Each one is flawed.

The Campaign-wide strategy could be very cool, as you earn astral power to augment your next map start, and you selectively choose what building upgrades you can get. Unfortunatly the astral power aspect is far too weak to have any reasonable changes on your map starts. So every map you start (which will be 10's if not 100's of times in a single campaign) is exactly the same thing. It gets repetitive.

The map strategy involves taking provinces and as you progress to diposing 1-N enemies on the map, but once you take a province you can instantly plop down a guard for the garrison, which is 1/10th the cost of the troops you would normally have to buy, and regularly a lot better than any troops anyone can produce. This means the game behoves rushing early on and plopping down guards, two of which the AI gains bonuses and cheats to accomplish.

Finally, the tactical combat is exeedingly simplistic. The AI does the same thing irrespective of the map or your compliment. There is no concept of threatened zones" around your characters
date: so AI troops will run through your line and attack things behind you
recommended: turning the game into just balling your troops up

votesTotal: while the "evil" kharma units are generally glass cannons. Since your world map size/complement would dictate which tactics you would want to do
votesFunny: the strategic aspects of kharma basically have negative correlary to the tactical aspects of kharma. Combined with the fact you're limited in the number of units you can build at any rank/tier
commentsCount: this means that if you start in a small shard with the zerg units (which since every shard is the same
column16: is almost always the best early option) you're now locked out of the other units.\n\nThe concept of the game is great
column17: but in practice the limits on troops

column20: but just purely pragmatic necessities."

reviewText:
Eador is billed as a stategy game and tries to combine Empire building 4x themes with turn based 'tactical' battles. Although the ideas are sound the execution is pretty bad. Everything seems a bit off at first and the feeling only grow the more you play it. Call it lack of polish or simply the mark of an 'indie' studio, the result is still the same...Not very fun.

The tactical battles as gimped with an impossibly small field of battle (units are constantly getting in each others way if you have more than 5-6 units and archers and mages can wipe you out from across the map) and poor unit balance. Even on the easiest difficulty level the fights go from very easy to frustrating. Before the battle the game gives you an indication of how tough a fight will be but even fights that You will win easily" can be a total wipe unless you use all your units in perfect coordination.

i wish I would have had the willpower to play more to see if it improves but the game is simply not fun..."

reviewText:
Let me start off by saying that I've been playing all types of strategy games for nearly 25 years.

This game has potential.  I found myself trying to figure out how to reach the higher level content once I managed to level my hero up.  Many of the quests were extremely hard at the beginning stages of the game and added to the frustration of leveling up.  Basic units are no match to even the most beginning level monsters".

The economy is unbalanced.   Unit maintenance is very high in relation to the amount of coin that you bring in from provinces.  Building costs are low which allows for quick building.   This will allow you to access units for purchase fairly quickly.  However
date: it doesn't seem to matter that much because there is a logistical issue with your hero only being able to hold 4 troop types at lower levels.  Even after leveling up to level 4
recommended: a hero still can only hold 4 troop types.  It is very difficult to level your units and keep your favorite units around.  Combat is unbalanced.\n\nI'm not sure if it's a bug
hoursPlayed:
but my garrison was transferred to another province when an uprising occured in that province.  I would expect the garrison to stand and fight.

The loot part of the game was very cool at first.  But there's no originality to the items.  Many of them are common low level items that don't help out too much.  Most of the game is loot based with low drop rates.

There are several bugs that cause the game to freeze/crash in the middle of the game.  This is not a huge issue though considering the game saves every 2 seconds.

If this game got some balance tweeks

reviewText:
I tried to like this game, I really did, but the game is way too unbalanced and way too RNG dependent in order to be good.

The game is pretty simple, kind of like some sort of Total War TBS. The object is to conquer shards by taking each enemy's capital, then move onto the next using advantages you gained in prior shards. Combat is grid based on a board with your soldiers. Each army is led by a hero and they all have their own special powers. Seems just like my kind of game.

UNFORTUNATELY... the game is just broken in a number of ways. The shards are randomly generated and sometimes you can just get a trash start where it's very difficult to take neutral territories while the AI proceeds to take everything else. And on the topic of the AI... its cheating is in a league of its own. I've never seen anything like it in a game. The AI will do insane things like get tier 2 guard units before you even have access to them in game, all but insuring capturing their capital is nearly impossible. The same with spells. Tier 4 spells that one shot your entire army, super rare items, endless pools of gold... I've had the exact situation, where the AI was down to maybe 4 provinces and I had the entire map, but they would pop out heroes and full armies like it was nothing, all while their capital was defended by Centaurs, a tier 2 unit, that would utterly destroy even the best army I could muster since I hadn't even unlocked any tier 2 units!! By the way, this was on the 3rd from lowest difficulty, where the game still gives you advantages. Even when you don't get completely screwed with RNG and do pretty well all this cheating makes the game extremely tedious. Especially the guards. More often than not you need to grind up to beat them, sometimes for a long, long time. And you know what? In  the end, the AI cheating really doesn't make it that much harder. It just makes it take much, much longer.

Add in some bugs plus a less than stellar UI and you have Eador in a nutshell. If it were less tedious it'd be a pretty fun game. As it is though? I suppose it's better than Warlock, but that's all I can really give it.

reviewText: I really tried to play it, because I love strategy games... but couldn't with so much bug. I'm feel sorry for that.

reviewText: I've never seen so much needless repetition in a game, which sucks because with a few tweaks Eador would be superb! But you will quickly see (within the first non-tutorial map) that the game is incredibly repetitive and grindy.\n\nThere is a concept of exploring provinces which is good but the execution is bad: Exploring takes many turns and you have to tell your heroes to Continue exploring" every. single. turn. You may even get more than one hero to do this
date: so you will be clicking OK a lot. This really should be automatic.\n\nYou can then "visit" the locations you have found while exploring
recommended: which you will usually do this with your strongest hero. When visiting locations
hoursPlayed:
any scouting information you accrued is lost and you're given no indication of the fight difficulty (if there is one) until you spend a turn. Both issues could have been covered in a 'are you sure?' prompt when selecting locations.

You're supposed to hire heroes and support them with an army. But I found it much easier to just hire a tough warrior hero and equip them with all the stuff you find from visiting locations. After a while they become invincible and can just stomp on everything. Armies are too expensive/upgrading heroes via equipment is too cheap.

Managing your kingdom is a horrible experience. You can only reinforce one village guard and build one building in one province per turn. Your kingdom will typically consist of dozens of provinces
voteText: making this incredibly tedious and difficult to keep track of. These limits could be removed.\n\nFinally
helpfulPercent: there are too many random events. They can fire off for multiple provinces every. single. turn. Many events have multiple stages
votesHelpful: depending on what choice you make. Do you care that there is a minor event in the insignificant province of Backwater Dump that might affect the citizens in some vague
votesTotal: indiscernable manner? The game believes you should. These events could have been more rare and had a larger impact.\n\nSo
votesFunny: Eador is entertaining and has great concepts but terrible execution. I can't recommend it when there are better games like it out there (Age of Wonders
commentsCount: Heroes of Might and Magic 3/5)."

reviewText:
I don't know what people's problem with this game is, it's pretty sweet to be honest. I don't know why there aren't more reviews or why the ones it does have are mixed.

It plays like Civ 5, but you choose a hero (mage, ranger, warrior) and you deck him out to take out enemies. You can get more heros later if you can afford them and deck them out and send to war as well. You recruit soldiers to build armies your heros can command, and there are lots of cool fantasy units you can get. There are casters and healers and tanks and archers you can unlock. More fantastical things are in too, like faries and ogres for example, if you conquer neighboring settlements, which you can do through bribes, diplomacy, quests or violence.

Technology is a little weird. You unlock new solder types not through a tech tree so much but by building things in your towns. Building upgrades and types offer higher tier soldiers and different soldier types as well as spells your dudes can use in combat. Army composition is important, you will take morale hits if you put in a bunch of paladins with zombies for example, so you want to watch that and recruit accordingly.

I got this game on sale but this title is worth the $20; as far as the dlc I bought it with the game so I can't really tell what all that added or not as I haven't looked at it seperately. It's only a few bucks though so may as well pick it up as well imo. I bought this as a cheaper alternative to Age of Wonders and Heros of Might and Magic, so I can't really compare it to them, but judging this game by itself I would say it is a fantastic game by its own merits.

reviewText:
Games are meant to be fun, not a chore to play.  This game is so close to being fun, but with the silly randomness of events and the rediculous amount of freebies the computer is awarded all aspects of enjoyment are gone.
I would rather say this game is recommended, but just cannot without that factor being present.

You need to first slowly, oh so slowly, level you starting hero in order to explore with you weak units in order to gain xp, gold and gems for encountering the computer opponents.  Then just when you can expand out farther the computer jumps in, starting at peace and hopefully remaining there long enough for you to gain units that can tackle the outer rings of territories.  Usually however you cannot get those units in enough time for the computer to declare war, and then steamroll over you with a hero that is 5 levels or more above yours and bringing in tier 3 (sometimes tier 4) units when you have only reached tier 2 units last turn.  Then on each level (shard) taking 2-3 hours to complete and then having no feeling of accomplishment ruins the game in my opinion.

There is just something missing.  Games can, and should, be hard, in order to advance mastery of the game for good, hard fun to occur; at some level of hard however a game becomes stupid.  This game is at the border of this at this time.

reviewText:
Eador is a game I have put off reviewing for quite some time and sitting down to play it I can remember why.
Difficult to learn, difficult to master, best sum up Eador.
If you are familiar with Heroes of Might and Magic then Eador is a familiar beast and just like those games you control a single hero who in turn controls an army. You are not limited to just one hero however and as long as you have the resources your army can be as big as you like.

I am going to assume however that you are unfamiliar with HoM&M and even if you are, Eador is a different beast altogether. It's main gimmick is shards, that is each map is its own contained world so when you conquer one shard you move onto the next.
The game also features an ambigious moral choice system and certain units do or do not like being teamed up with others. Holy Paladins for example are not pleased by having to work with blood sucking vampires and such combinations will affect morale. Let morale get too low and units will flee the battlefield.

Already you can see a lot of systems are in play in this game and it isn't a bad game either. Complex doesn't have to mean 'bad' or 'begineer-unfriendly' but many things are randomized. You might get a start location with nearby provinces you have little chance of taking over and no resources to bribe them with. A province by the way is akin to a second city or to extending your domain so basically you want them if you can get them.

I really could go on and on about every little system but a game stands or falls on one thing. Is it fun? For me Eador is middle ground. It is not a bad game at all and if you like games such as Civilization 5 or Endless Legend you will find yourself slowly adapting to Eador but for me I grew up on Heroes of Might & Magic so I want to love Eador and instead I find myself being SUPER ANNOYED at the game lying to me so much!

3 Medusas? Yeah it'll be fine, we'll slaughter them. Lied the game shortly before I reloaded my last save.
6 Peasants? We stand no chance! Lied the game again and I wiped them out with no issues.

Lying is a harsh word but that is certainly what it feels like at times. The game will tell you that wizards can attack at range, but forgets to tell you that they need a wand to do so. A wizard is a hired hero and hiring is expensive so if your wizard doesn't come with a wand, your hosed. You have to spend more money to build a shop that sells wands.
The game will tell you that a unit has a certain range like 3 or 4 but you get into a fight and it forgets to mention all the modifiers that effect the range like trees or hills.
And this is the begineer difficulty, with tutorials turned on!

As you get better at the game you learn to ignore the lies as you have a good idea of what kills what and who to fight or who to avoid but I can't help but feel like Eador sabotaged itself. This game should be as big as the remade Kings Bounty games with over a million copies shifted or something I mean this game is good enough to be a Civ5 contender, but due to the steep learning curve I imagine many people are just turned off and stop playing, I know I did.

Music is more of background noise, I honestly mentally tuned it out. Sound effects are funny, spiders sounds like jewels falling down an escalator but as I always say about sound effects, they are not the biggest factor. Graphics? Game looks wonderful! Really, the art is great it really is and their is so much of it you won't take it all in until after a few hours of playing.

Overall Eador is a niche game for a niche market and that is a huge shame. I stand by what I said when I said this game should be up there as a contender for Civ5 but as it stands many will have looked Eador over for Endless Legend and I personally think Eador is the better game but its amazing the difference some handholding and a tutorial can do.
The game does have a manual but I think that should be within the game itself like Civ5's civilpedia.

I can't recommend this game to the majority of people but if you read this far then you will have a good idea if this is the kind of game for you or not, for most people they will struggle to get into this game and when they do the small playerbase will struggle to keep them.

Join Grumpy reviews for all your gaming needs
http://steamcommunity.com/groups/grumpyreviews

reviewText:
I'd really like to recommend this game, but I can't, really.

It's just so good in its basic premise, and the execution is not half bad either, but some bad design and balance decisions make it a sad game to play. After a while you understand just how badly the AI cheats, how only one character class is truly good (warrior, solo all enemies, all armies), and the crash bugs finally get to you..

In short, I probably wouldn't get this unless the game balance is addressed.
If you got a fun and balanced game, even crash bugs don't bother you because you just reboot it and continue. A bad game, even if technically perfect, you just won't want to play at all

reviewText: This game is intriguing at first, and the tutorial even tricks you into thinking it will be fun. This is far from the reality of the game. In truth, even the beginning difficulty level is more frustrating than it is worth. I have tried multiple strategies from single to multiple heroes of different classes, conservative and liberal spending. None of it matters. By the time you get any momentum in the game you are harried by your opponent and relentlessly picked off. If resources were plentiful this would be an acceptable challenge as you could build your defenses, hire support, and actually dream to achieve something. The problem is that when this happens you are typically stretched. Conservative play is likely key, but to be honest - I don't f*ing play a game to sit around for hours twiddling my thumbs. Yes, it's strategy, but different people like different strategy. I for one do not like this one. I'd rather play Civ, or most any other tactics game. Save your time and money - and buy something better.

reviewText:
+ The overworld is nice looking.
+ Has a cute town upgrade system that shows the new buildings and technologies.
+ Units and monsters are detailed and well animated, though some animations are over-long.


+ / - Quite slow and very long. Each province needs capturing, then you can usually fight one or two side battles there straight away, then upgrade it (one building per turn only), then 'exploring' to quell overpopulation (about 5% explored per turn, totally automated, no actual walking around or exploration) which uncovers more battles. With over a dozen provinces per stage there is an awful lot of content, albeit drip-fed.

- Unfulfilling, slow combat.
- Even with a huge advantage, using the auto-battle will get half your force killed.
- The battles really don't have much to do with 'strategy and tactics'. The battlefields are so small, so full of terrain and your army so comparatively huge that you almost run out of room to deploy them (leading to just plonking them down wherever you can), units get in each other's way, leading to fiddly, grindy crawls across a map dominated by choke points. Pretty shallow, more about numbers than anything else.

If you like more board-gamey strategy games (like FF Tactics) then you might like this. But otherwise, don't bother.
