reviewText:
You can blame me for not playing it enough, but after over 10h of playtime, the game did not get me hooked, not at all.
And i honestly think it's sad. The art is amazing, the sound atmospheric, the story... might be interesting, i can barely tell though and i think you can see the love and thought which went into this game, there are a lot of nice concepts packed into it. But, for me, the actual gameplay is so horrible that i don't even want to touch it anymore despite all the things that seem so nice about it.

Here is why: I like turn based strategy games, i've been playing Heroes of Might and Magic (oh no, so mainstream?!) since decades, tried every installement and Eador reminds me very much of it. But, while Heroes is definetly not the fastest game, it has a pace i can go along with, its mechanics interlock well into one another (usually, not the same for all of them and all the titles), so it is nice to be invested in them, fighting your way through the campaign with what little things might be given to you, or watching your puny town thrive to a huge empire in an open game, or make to many or one big mistake and probably fail. I think, this is not the case in Eador. There is a lot you can do, but to me none of it felt like i was achieving anything. Spending dozens of turns to explore one area, most of which is delivered in text, sometimes fighting encounters, most of which appeared meaningless to me, sometimes dieing to a threat i couldn't even determine beforehand, or when the game even told me this should be easy" and my units get one-hitted one after another

reviewText:
This game is addictive, and the game play is fun, but they have some serious file handling errors.  Their file handling errors manifest it two ways.  The first is that if you try to attack the wrong shard the game will crash during the first save event.  The second is that if you try to attack the wrong enemy on a shard and the game will freeze.   I don’t know what’s going on, but this is pretty basic stuff.  It is kind of surprising that they could create the graphics and gameplay that they have and yet still not even manage programing 101 file handling issues.
Here’s the use case that ruins the game for me.  I have three shards that I can attack.  Two of them will cause the game to crash during the first save event.  The third freezes every time I try to invade a territory controlled by the last of four enemies.  As such, there is now no way for me to even attempt to continue, let alone win, the game.  I guess that I could just kill off all of my heroes, dismiss all of my guards and troops, and then wait for the last enemy to conquer my castle, but who would want to do that?  Besides, there is no guarantee that surrendering this shard will allow for the creation of a shard that won’t crash.
It looks like this game will be really fun someday.  But until they fix there file handling issues it is just frustrating.  As such, I wouldn’t recommend buying it until after they fix these bugs.

reviewText:
Apperently the game is entirely or borderline broken on some systems. I played this a bunch when I first bought. Shame. It's a great game, on level with HOMM3, I'd say, but I cannot recommend a game that has a risk of simply not working no matter what you do.

reviewText:
The tutorial took 3 hours and that was one of the most boring experiences I've ever had playing a video game.  I honestly can't think of a worse way to introduce your game to new players then what I just went through.

The basic game mechanics seemed backwards compared to every other game of this genre I've played.  Why would you make a move then wait for next turn to see how that move worked out, why doesn't it just happen now...

Other overworld mechanics appeared to exist only to increase the amount of grinding" you could achieve as a player.  The combat mechanics were even worse
date: the basic UI had enough numbers floating around that you would generally have no idea what nay of them specifically meant.  The "guide" dialouge to tell you how difficult an encounter would be how wrong about as often as it was right.\n\nThe music was repetitive beyond all measure
recommended:
the sound effects and animations were amateurish.

This game may have been a competitor with Heroes of Might and Magic 1 but nothing in that genre that's been created sense.

It is possible that if you're willing to give this game more of a chance then I did there is a good game waiting for you on the other end
hoursPlayed: but I can't imagine it."

reviewText: I'm on the fence about this game. On one hand it is a fairly fun. The game structure works for me, but there is a lot of missed potential. The AI is either too easy, or just tedious to play against. The story mode takes too long before you unlock even half the units. I'm 40 hours in and have unlocked about half. reviewText:
Found this game to be very repetitive and the only play style that worked for me was to be aggressive with the hero from the go. Since if you go slow, the enemy hero finds you and walks right through all your defences.  Whoever has the strongest hero wins especially with the weak units you use for most of the game, the hero can crush entire armies when he gets high enough and the mage class is useless for the most part.

The campaign is like an endless restarting skirmish mode, where you start off the same each time with maybe a couple different enviromental effects and the possiblity of one more building which you earned last time. This gets old fast and it almost seems like you aren't making any progress with a vague reason to keep you going.

So if you are wanting one or two skirmishes its ok, it also look and plays fine. Would however only say to get this game if its on sale to play a little to see what its like but for the most part its too repetitive for me.

reviewText:
Well, some nice ideas, but done really really badly, and overall it quickly get's boring.

Instead of something really creative, most of the hero progress/cash gain is thorugh random events generated by exploring".  And realy while you theoretically can have many heroes for a HUGE part of each game you will walk with single army.  Basically because for one thing you will not be able to buy and maintain 2 heroes (even with easiest setting you will burn out starting gold too fast without building up the armies/heroes to conquer anything)
And the difficulty of encounters is badly scaled - at the beginning you struggle in each fight
date:
and then very suddenly you trample most enemies.

There are still many bugs. For example before each encounter the game describes the opponent and tries to give some sumary on the chances.
Not only the "estimate" is most often dead wrong ("no losses" is impossible and from some "hard" fights you come unscrathed). And that is particularily annoying because sometimes some bug causes the part of description with enemies

While the city building and expanse seems interesting and complex at first
recommended: it quickly becomes obvious it's really primitive. This is because in longer run most of the possible building choices are not really viable (You can build almost useless trash buildings or buy the few needed or save the cash)\n\nWhile your troops can gain experience and level
hoursPlayed: in most cases it affects them in pretty minimal way. And the game fight system is not setup in a way that would promote the "leveling" of units
voteText: as they are hard to level and easy to kill.\n\nOverall the game suffers from randomness in just about anything."

reviewText:
GRRR...  Why didn't I listen?  I read all the reviews and heard how bad this game was.  Some reason I decided to buy the game anyway.

Positive Details:
..1.  It plays like an advanced Heros of Might and Magic.
..2.  Good graphics.

Negative Details:
..1.  The game is full of unfinished failures.
.....a.   Units will die before the attacker even arrives.
.....b.   Units will die before the attacker draws his weapon.
.....c.   Many times the graphics will just slide across the screen

[I DON'T WANT THE NORMAL DEVELOPER EXCUSE!  I AM NOT A CHILD!  I HAVE THE LATEST HARDWARE AND MATCHING DRIVERS!]

..2.  The game is extremely repetitive.
.....a.  Build buildings
.....b.  Build units
.....c.  Fight
.....d.  and repeat ad infinitum

..3.  The story is lame

..4.  You start so weak you spend all your time waiting to get strong before you can do anything.

[Good game design would have allowed the enemies to scale equal to the players growth. Perhaps  like every RPG and strategy game made in the last three decades.]

I tried liking this game, but I am not wasting any more time on it!

reviewText:
Grab it on sale, if it sounds interesting to you. Otherwise... skip it.

I have played 3 days worth on it and I honestly can't say any one part of it wants me to come back to try it again after letting it go for a while.

Don't get me wrong, it has elements and aspects that are just begging to be a great game - but it is just not mixed well enough to make it there. Pieces of the game's RNG engine that determines the perks you gain by shards play havok with how to progress, making the game mixture so unevel you'll go through the game and realize you missed out on over two-thirds of the content for no real reason.

It has so much, but so little to make you inclined to use it, its almost... forgettable.
To me, that's kinda sad, especially since I can clearly remember the gameplay as to actually be that good, addictive one more turn" element to it.

It has promise
recommended: but the mixture on how its done makes it so uneven you'll forget what you could have done after you finish it.\n\nIts a passable game
hoursPlayed: about averate of what's to expect for the turn-based strategy - but nothing truly noteworthu  outside its concept. Some growth and development aspects that limit and help lean the player towards one style or another are truly good
voteText: but it cuts out so much of viable options thanks to the sheer quantity its such a shame on the balance scale of what could have been."

It's just extremely extremely extremely repetitive. For every new shard, play with a brand new hero. Build the exact same buildings and units over. Fight the same battles in the same way over.

Part of the problem is that it's not balanced. Certain units are just SO superior to others, and the difficulty can be punishing, which has you using those same units and fighting in the same way over and over.

reviewText:
Eador: Masters of the Broken World... What has it brought to us? A fine picture, a new DLC (which you will rarely use to your advantage) and a damn lot of bugs!
First of all, the game is not optimized at all! Its graphics are not so great, because it's just a turn-based strategy, but is uses more resources than Skyrim until it just refuses to work. Relaunching the game may help, but I want to play, not launch it over and over again. But that's not all. Tons of bugs still occur after so many updates. Devs, are you sure you fix them? I don't see it. Just two days ago, it crashed, when I attempted to conquer a new shard and no matter how many times I reloaded the game and the save file, it was crashing in the same place. Do I have to begin it from the very beginning after so many hours of playing to get the same error again someday?! Oh, come on...
New DLC... Yeah, it's fun sometimes, but that's not what I expected. It could have been much better! You just have some new units for the creatures you can make an alliance with, but if you have a troll or a minotaur, then you won't use them at all, because they are too week. And completing some tasks becomes more difficult, because, if you need to kill 10 dwarves, you'll have to kill 100 dwarves and that's not funny at all.
Tastes differ, I know, but I liked the Eador: Genesis's interface more. It looked better and worked better. It was more convenient.
Another thing that I did not like at all! The game has become easier! A damn lot easier compared to Eador: Genesis. When you attempt to conquer a shard, you've got 3-4 new building to acquire... When you finally conquer a shard, you get 7-8 new buildings! And how am I supposed to call that bonus? Yeah, a piece of s**t! It just ruins all the fun! You don't have to plan ahead, you don't have to choose wisely which shard you should conquer next. And in the end (if you get to it, because it can crash anytime, as I mentioned above) you have to (yes, you HAVE to) conquer EMPTY shards! And you know what? It pisses me off to waste time like that!
The result: yes, Eador: Genesis is older, it doesn't have that pretty though useless DLC, it's not 3D, it doesn't have these pretty (also quite useless though) achievements in Steam, but it works well and it's more challenging, and that is why I'll choose that old beauty instead of this new piece of garbage! So, as you have already guessed, I do NOT recommend it!

reviewText: I really wanted to like this and played it a good amount, but there's really too much in the game. You can explore a single province and tackle it's encountes a ton, which is generally more valuable than the eXpand part of 4x. There's sort of multiple meta games, the adventure and the mega map.\n\nIn theory, that'd be right up my ally, but in practice it doesn't mesh well. Plus, you MUST have your heroes survive and level and also your units. You can't really ever fail and expect to win, which makes the game a try-reload tactical battle experience rather than a 4x experience.

reviewText:
If you were ever fond of the HoMM series but always thought it could use a little Civilization, then this may be the game for you.....Just kidding. Wait until it is at least 75% off or more because, although the ideas are there and it has a decent core like province exploration or the battle system, it lacks with a very tedious middle game on every shard and it constantly crashes on me. The crashes happen mainly when it is loading a large or massive shard but it happens a little too often for me when I'm just ending a turn.

Overall, a 6 / 10 game. It needs some love and care from the developers to polish it off. If it never receives that though, maybe don't bother.


PS. More than $20 to begin with this game is kind of criminal.

reviewText:
Excellent, truly excellent game. I am a player of fantasy based games and this stands out as one of the best. True, it is a game that will challenge you greatly, maybe even frustrate you at the start but the campaign is very well thought out and enjoyable with several threads. The sandbox game allows you to choose levels of difficulty and size of the shard that you wish to conquer.

You might want to follow Martin Fencka's Lets Play on Youtube as I have learned so much from following him as he has played through over 300 parts of an LP. Its a complex game but extremely rewarding.

As I write this review, you can buy the game at 80% off. A great opportunity to open up hours of challenging gameplay.

reviewText:
THIS GAME HAS A LOW SCORE BECAUSE IT USED TO BE COMPLETELY BROKEN
having said that, here is my review.

++faction customization, as you go
+broad scope of units
+vastly non linear gameplay
+many ways to play

-limited provence interaction
-no smooth transition between easy and hard

Conclusion: VERY GOOD

gonna be short on this one, but do you like RPGs? Do you like strategy? Do you like character building? this is the game for you. Built around forming your faction as you go rather then just making you choose from a set of premade ones the game offers many branching paths for development of both your faction in terms of religion, culture, military, and magic, aswell as for your avatar. There's plenty of hidden things and random encounters to mix things up, aswell as mercs and special weapons to buff your armies. The province interaction is very limited though, and the game suffers from the occasional bug, the difficulty curve is also a bit too steep.
Also multiplayer would be good, if anyone still played this game... I give Eador a 7/10

reviewText:
UPDATE 1/2016:

A lot of the bugs seem to be fixed, though a few might remain. I'm switching this to a *very cautious* thumbs up. (By the way, my hours in the game are exaggerated. One of the many bugs is that when the game crashed, it didn't end the process in the task manager. So, I once had the process running for a week straight, adding a couple hundred hours to my play time).

ORIGINAL REVIEW BELOW:

So many bugs! I really really want to enjoy this game. And for long stretches, I do enjoy it... and then a gamebreaking bug causes all of my progress to be lost. This happens over and over again. I keep coming back, so at its heart it is a good game. Every time there is a patch to fix a bug, several new bugs pop up in its place.

Most recently, they put out a big patch, calling it free DLC, and supposedly fixed bugs. It introduced an obvious, gamebreaking bug right up front that makes the game unplayable (enemy units won't die, they just sit on the battlefield at 0 health).

Here is a list of some other bugs I've encountered in previous builds, some of which may still be present (I don't know, since the game is unplayable on the first shard now)

1) I attacked another master, and won the final battle to take the shard. This results in a game over" screen (this ruined my longest campaign
date: and even happened when I went to beat a different shard first
recommended: then returned to that master).\n2) My provinces are invincible. An enemy master will defeat my guards at a province
hoursPlayed: then retreat the next turn
voteText: with the province still under my control and my guards at full health\n3) I attack a province and end up in a mirror match
helpfulPercent: where I control both of my identical armies against one another. No matter which side wins
votesHelpful: I both win and lose the battle.\n4) Game freezing and crashing to desktop immediately after conquering a shard. It goes to the main astral screen
votesTotal: the conquered shard comes towards my shard
votesFunny:
and the game crashes as soon as they merge.
5) The enemy AI completely forgetting to play the game. I once took over an entire master's shard with the enemy hero having never been beyond one hex of his capital. This was on a large map.

I cannot recommend this game in its current state. It's been a year of heartache for me
commentsCount: since I want to play through a campaign so badly
column16: and I keep trying
column17: but it's just getting worse."
